Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Barbara Baker was sentenced to 10 years in prison for shoplifting clothes to support her heroin habit.

While she was serving her sentence, Barbara was in a work-release program. During the day, she worked in the community as a certified nursing assistant. At night, she’d return to her prison cell. On one occasion, a friend was selling drugs. Heroin was all she could think about.

She bought some.

Barbara took a hit and kept working. Tired from a long shift, she slept hard that night. She woke up in a panic. The guards knew that inmates were using drugs and she was on the list for a drug test. All of a sudden, everything she had worked for – including the time reduction for good behavior she earned – was at risk. It might be even longer before she saw her son and daughter again.

“If I make it out of this, I will never use again,” she prayed. That day, the guards didn’t ask her for a urine sample.

Barbara never did drugs again and served six and a half years of her 10-year sentence.

It’s been 24 years since Barbara was in prison. What she knows now is that she shoplifted to feed her addiction. Barbara went to prison five different times, spending a total of 15 and a half years of her life behind bars. No one had ever asked why she did what she did.

The real crime here is a failed justice system, where people receive unnecessarily harsh sentences and the disease of addiction is left untreated.

TAKE ACTION: Write a letter to your representatives today and ask them to take a stand for criminal justice reform.

Missouri has the eighth-highest incarceration rate in the nation and the fastest growing female prison population in the country. Women arrested for drug offenses increased 49 percent between 2010 and 2015. “The War on Drugs is a war on women, on families,” says Barbara, who is now the advocacy director for Center for Women in Transition, a St. Louis-based nonprofit that helps women recently released from prison.

For the past 18 years, Barbara has worked to offer women the same support that changed her life forever. “I came out of jails desperate, looking for a way to stay out. I would get out, get a job, get a house, get my children and then I would relapse – in that order,” Barbara says.

She knows that for people to be successful, we must offer alternatives to prison that treat addiction as a disease, not a crime. As you look to take action on MLK Day, start by helping those behind bars. “If you believe in civil rights, fight for criminal justice reform,” says Barbara.

Write to your legislators and demand criminal justice reform as the number one priority.

The time is ripe for change. Join Barbara and the ACLU in our fight for smarter justice in Missouri.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Sara E. Baker
Legislative and Policy Director , ACLU of Missouri
